title: 106_hr4673
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Support for Overseas Cooperative Development Act". The Congress finds that promoting cooperatives and credit unions benefits the US and developing countries economically. These self-help institutions allow for democratic decision-making, ownership of businesses, and mobilization of local capital. The US aims to support economic and social development through agricultural cooperatives. Cooperatives play a vital role in lifting low-income farmers and rural people out of poverty, providing essential services like credit, electricity, telecommunications, housing, and insurance. Cooperatives provide risk protection for life and property to underserved populations through group policies. Cooperatives provide risk protection for life and property to underserved populations through group policies. General provisions are outlined in SEC. 3. The Congress supports economic assistance programs utilizing cooperatives and credit unions, focusing on international cooperative principles, self-help savings mobilization, market-oriented activities for low-income individuals, strengthening participation of rural and urban poor, and utilizing technical assistance and training. In meeting development priorities, specific focus is given to agriculture, financial systems, and infrastructure through technical assistance and training to low-income farmers forming cooperatives, promoting national credit union systems, and establishing rural electric infrastructure. The establishment of rural electric and telecommunication cooperatives for universal access in rural areas lacking reliable services, along with promoting community-based cooperatives providing employment opportunities, health clinics, self-help shelter, and group-owned businesses. SEC. 4. REPORT.

Within 6 months of this Act's enactment, the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, in consultation with relevant agencies, must submit a report to Congress on the implementation of section 111 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961.
